description: From Middle English whitenen, whitnen, from Old Norse hvítna (“to whiten”), from Proto-Germanic *hwītnōną (“to whiten, become white”), from Proto-Indo-European *kwind-, *kwint- (“bright”), equivalent to white +‎ -en. Cognate with Icelandic hvítna (“to whiten”), Swedish vitna, hvitna (“to whiten”), Danish hvidne (“to whiten”). Compare Old English hwītian (“to whiten, become white, be white, make white”).

verbs.description: whiten (third-person singular simple present whitens, present participle whitening, simple past and past participle whitened)

entries.meaning: (ergative) (To cause) to become white or whiter; to bleach or blanch.
examples: The trees in spring whiten with blossoms.
